item.title: The Lede: Republican Ideas on Immigration Could Legalize Up to 6.5 Million, Study Says
item.description: “Half a loaf” proposals may put many more on a so-called path to citizenship than immigrant advocates have previously thought.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: A Dream Action Coalition demonstration last month.

item.title: Flow of Westerners to Syria Prompts Security Concerns
item.description: The assertion may have been meant to create an impression that Western opposition to the tenure of President Bashar al-Assad is not as absolute as Western politicians have suggested.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Arab Neighbors Take Split Paths in Constitutions
item.description: Tunisia and Egypt, whose revolts ignited the Arab Spring, provide a dual lesson in the pitfalls and potentials for democracy in the region as they move toward new charters.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK and CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Tuesday, soldiers helped a man into a polling station in Cairo, where Egyptians were set to vote in the third referendum on the constitution in three years.

item.title: Global Piracy Hits Lowest Level Since 2007, Report Says
item.description: The International Maritime Bureau attributed the drop mostly to a sharp decline in piracy off Somalia’s coast.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Bowe Bergdahl, G.I. Long Held by Afghan Militants, Is Seen in Video
item.description: A video of an American held captive for four and a half years has been obtained by the U.S. government, and officials said that it showed him in declining health.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THOM SHANKER

item.title: Pope Names Cardinals to Oversee Vatican Bank
item.description: Pope Francis replaced all but one of the appointees made by his predecessor, Benedict XVI, in another example of how the new pope is consolidating power.
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY and GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Tensions Between Afghanistan and U.S. Increase as Airstrike Kills Civilians
item.description: A coalition airstrike in a province north of Kabul killed at least two villagers, prompting President Hamid Karzai to order an inquiry.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: The Lede: L’Affaire Hollande
item.description: The frenzy of interest in the French press over the reported liaison between President François Hollande and an actress, Julie Gayet, has laid bare that the vaunted privacy of a French president is an illusion.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: A Harder Look at Welfare Rules as Europeans Flood Countries in Search of Jobs
item.description: At a time when government austerity policies have led to cuts, Europe’s debate over immigration has become intertwined with a thorny discussion of the costs of welfare.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Senate Report Finds Benghazi Attack Was Preventable
item.description: A stinging report by the Senate Intelligence Committee blames both American diplomats and spies for poor communication and lax security before the deadly 2012 episode in Libya.
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI

item.title: China Dwarfs U.S. in Monetary Stimulus
item.description: The amount of money sloshing the economy, according to a broad measure, has tripled since 2006 and has driven asset prices through the roof.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 15
item.description: Jallikattu, a bull-taming sporting event, was held in Palamedu, Tamil Nadu.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A participant during a bull-taming sport called Jallikattu in Palamedu, Tamil Nadu. It is an event held during the harvest festival of Pongal in the state.

item.title: French Leader Brushes Aside Questions Over Affair
item.description: Invoking his right to privacy, President François Hollande said at a news conference that everyone suffers “difficult moments.”
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: In a highly anticipated news conference at the Élysée Palace on Tuesday, President François Hollande of France drew an audience seeking more than policy news.

item.title: U.S. Pledges $380 Million in Relief Aid for Syria
item.description: At a donors’ conference in Kuwait, the host nation said it would contribute $500 million, while Saudi Arabia and Qatar each offered $60 million.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Pablo Martinez Monsivais
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry delivered remarks at a conference in Kuwait on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: A Pocket Guide to the 2014 Jaipur Literature Festival
item.description: From Friday through Tuesday, celebrated writers from India and abroad will talk about not just their books but also about the two World Wars, Afghanistan after the withdrawal of American troops, Himalayan languages and the making of modern China.
item.dc:creator: By AAYUSH SONI
item.media:description: Author Jhumpa Lahiri with her book 'The Lowland' at the Queen Elizabeth Hall in London on Oct. 13, 2013.

item.title: Thousands March Against Thai Leader in 3rd Day of Protests
item.description: A protester was shot and the compound of a former prime minister, Abhisit Vejjajiva, was damaged by a small explosion during the unrest.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Protesters ducked behind a barricade after hearing three gunshots in Bangkok early Wednesday.

item.title: Scores Die as Militants in Iraq Unleash Attacks
item.description: The latest deaths brought the number of people killed in the last three days to more than 80.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: Civilians and security forces at the site of a car bomb attack on Wednesday near the Technology University in Baghdad.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Leader Skirts Democracy Issue in Address
item.description: The comments by Leung Chun-ying, the territory’s chief executive, did little to clarify whether Hong Kong would allow all adults to vote in the next election.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Kerry Brushes Aside Israeli Official’s Reported Criticisms of Peace Effort
item.description: A news report that the Israeli defense minister thinks John Kerry’s efforts are naïve and messianic drew criticism from Washington and some Israeli leaders.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Ariel Hermoni/Israeli Defense Ministry, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: Comments by Israel’s defense minister, Moshe Yaalon, were described by unidentified sources.

item.title: Letter from India: Manmohan Singh’s Harder Path
item.description: The Indian prime minister pushed through important legislation despite long odds and sharp criticism.
item.dc:creator: By MANU JOSEPH
item.media:description: Prime Minster Manmohan Singh of India at a press conference Jan. 3 at which he announced that he would not seek office if his party returned to power.

item.title: German Economy Grew Just 0.4 Percent in 2013 but Picking Up Steam
item.description: The economy saw its worst performance since the global financial crisis in 2009, with strong domestic demand only partially offsetting the negative impact of the euro crisis.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: State Television Airs Footage of Major Drug Raid
item.description: The assault on a Guangdong village in December by 3,000 officers ended in 182 arrests for suspected manufacture of methamphetamine.
item.dc:creator: By MIA LI

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: American Life Turns Off One Chinese Student
item.description: A news agency employee who went to the United States to study film editing says now all he wants to do is return to the land of the Chinese Dream.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Students walk across the Princeton University campus. Two years in the United States have left one Chinese student yearning to return home to work for the Chinese Dream.

item.title: Administration Is Seen as Retreating on Environment in Talks on Pacific Trade
item.description: Documents obtained by WikiLeaks show that the Obama administration is pulling back on environmental protections to reach a trade deal that is a pillar of the president’s strategic shift to Asia.
item.dc:creator: By CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Spring Gala Performance by Chinese Rock Icon in Doubt
item.description: The invitation to Cui Jian, whose songs became anthems of the 1989 pro-democracy student movement, was seen as an attempt to enliven one of the world’s most watched programs. But his agent cited concerns about censorship.
item.dc:creator: By LUO TIAN
item.media:credit: Goh Chai Hin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
